alert.note: Alert for Bastrop; Caldwell; De Witt; Fayette; Gonzales; Lavaca; Lee (Texas) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Red Flag Warning issued March 28 at 2:51PM CDT until March 28 at 8:00PM CDT by NWS Austin-San Antonio
info.description: ...CRITICAL FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS CONTINUE THROUGH MONDAY AFTERNOON... Low relative humidities and gusty winds continue this afternoon. Minimum RH values in the low 20s to mid 30s are expected along and west of Highway 281 and in the mid 30 to low 40s farther east along the U.S. 77 corridor. South to southeast winds will increase to 15 to 20 mph with gusts between 20 and 30 mph this afternoon and early evening. Slightly more humidity is expected Tuesday, but there will be also a stronger south winds of around 25 mph with gusts up to 40 mph. Despite not strictly meeting criteria, this combination of dry air and moderate winds will lead to near critical to critical fire weather conditions and with ongoing fires in the area the decision was made to issue another Red Flag Warning from 10am-8pm today and again Tuesday for most of South Central Texas. Fuels remain unusually dry, and this is leading to an active season of wildfires that are difficult to contain. Any outdoor activity that could lead to the development of sparks and resulting wildfire potential is highly discouraged! ...RED FLAG WARNING REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 8 PM CDT THIS EVENING FOR WIND AND LOW RELATIVE HUMIDITY ACROSS ALL OF SOUTH CENTRAL TEXAS... ...ELEVATED FIRE WEATHER CONDITIONS CONTINUE FOR TUESDAY FOR GUSTY WINDS AND DRY CONDITIONS... * WINDS...South 15 to 20 mph with gusts up to 35 mph. * RELATIVE HUMIDITY...Minimums 30 TO 45 percent. * IMPACTS...Any wildfires ignited may spread rapidly and unpredictably. Prevention of fire starts by avoiding planned burning, or by limiting activities prone to produce sparks. Take care to stop the start and spread of wildfires.
info.instruction: A Red Flag Warning means that critical fire weather conditions are either occurring now....or will shortly. A combination of strong winds...low relative humidity...and warm temperatures can contribute to extreme fire behavior.
